stream_context.summary: Kaze streams from his PC while working on two parallel tasks: polishing a large Bowser-factory level for Return to Yoshi’s Island (course still untitled, internally described as an oil/fuel "Fleet Factory") and prototyping a huge vertical "Only Up 64" stage for a SimpleFlips competition.  The session focuses on designing a seesaw set-piece that squashes a safety-helmet Goomba, testing performance on real N64 hardware, and roughing-out a new construction-worker Womp enemy.

development_findings.summary: Created a 60 %-complete vertical challenge map named “Only Up 64,” intended to be the biggest Mario 64 level ever (≈25 min climb) and to remain N64-compatible.
development_findings.quote: This will be the biggest level ever made on Mario 64… It’s gonna take like 25 minutes just to get to the top.

development_findings.summary: Redesigned Tox Boxes with higher-resolution textures and more expressive faces; still needs wall-collision fix to stop Mario clipping through them.
development_findings.quote: I still have to think of a way to make it so that Mario can't move through the walls like this—it's a bit difficult.

development_findings.summary: Implemented new global collision routines that give noticeably more stable ceiling/slope interaction.
development_findings.quote: You guys probably can't really tell the difference but it’s very noticeable when you're walking into ceilings—it’s a lot more stable now.

development_findings.summary: Prototyped a seesaw gimmick: Mario breaks a rear crate, plank pivots forward, flattens a Goomba, then settles; built custom sine-driven animation, added bounce tuning, and tested on console.
development_findings.quote: I want the player to be able to stop it while Mario is still on there and, once past a point, it just spins out of control and squishes him.

development_findings.summary: Diagnosed and fixed an N64 crash caused by GCC inserting a divide-by-zero in a branch delay slot; added ε (0.01f) safeguard and patched both main and Only Up repos.
development_findings.quote: The compiler pipelined the division into the delay slot so I always divide by zero—that’s not my fault.

development_findings.summary: Performance pass on the factory level: 13k tris raw, 6k without text; worst-case 19 FPS → 25–29 FPS by enabling back-face culling for metal scaffolds only on hardware; plans include collision maps, triangle trimming, and optional area splits.
development_findings.quote: Backface culling is insane—going from 22 to 29 FPS just by flipping that flag.

development_findings.summary: Designed construction-worker Womp: flat-shaded body, safety belt across face, helmet strapped to back; will carry steel beams and be toppled by Mario; animation scheduled next stream.
Sound system has five unused footstep surface slots; metal step SFX may be replaced and general sound-design postponed until end of development.
development_findings.quote: We still have space for, I think, five sound-step games… I want to see the hat right now.

development_findings.summary: Memory strategy: game currently requires Expansion Pak; technically could be squeezed into 4 MB by loading areas and codes separately, but “a lot of extra work for very little gain.”

context_findings.summary: Kaze lost his Brilliant sponsorship; YouTube channel is now only “barely profitable,” limiting ability to pay collaborators.
context_findings.quote: My YouTube channel is barely profitable, especially now that Brilliant doesn't sponsor me anymore—kind of back to square zero.

context_findings.summary: Maintains separate ‘Kaze Clips’ stream channel to avoid hurting main-channel algorithm and to filter viewers to people who actually care about the game.
context_findings.quote: I stream on Kaze Clips because we have 10,000 subs here… I don't want to ruin my algorithm on the main channel.

context_findings.summary: Expresses philosophy that code should be self-documenting and comments are often redundant.
context_findings.quote: The code itself is better documentation than your documentation, so you should remove your documentation.

context_findings.summary: Struggling with YouTube latency; discovered but couldn’t fully fix ‘low-latency’ toggle—30 s lag persists.
Mentions heavy workload: building Only Up 64, preparing a tech-conference presentation, and core game tasks—"I will never have my freedom."
Personal: heat wave (‘literally gonna die from this heat’), occasional humor about age and online slang, and casual interaction with chat for song requests.

biobak.summary: Actively provides texture/visual feedback in chat; Kaze credits him for trailer submissions for F3 event; lighthearted banter about subscriber counts.
biobak.quote: Oh shit, that's… actually, is that sad or neat, Biobak? It's neat for me, sad for you.

badub.summary: Expected to compose track for current level but has been ‘missing in attendance,’ leaving OST plan uncertain.
badub.quote: I thought Badub was gonna make a song but Badub's been missing for a bit, so I'm not really sure what to expect.

zeina.summary: Supplied new enemy animations (“this guy already or most of them”) but is absent this stream; Kaze mentions she is out with friends.
zeina.quote: Zeina made the animations for this guy already—or most of them.

key_stories.title: Back-face Culling Boosts FPS
key_stories.summary: The factory level dipped to 19 FPS on real hardware.  By toggling back-face culling for two metal materials exclusively on N64 builds, Kaze raised worst-case performance to ~25-29 FPS without visible loss on console.
key_stories.challenge: Severe frame-rate drops in a 13k-triangle area.
key_stories.process: Profiled angles, counted triangles, selectively enabled back-face culling, retested on console.
key_stories.outcome: Performance is now considered acceptable; further gains will come from collision maps and triangle pruning.
key_stories.key_quote: Backface culling is insane—going from 22 to 29 FPS just by flipping that flag.

key_stories.title: Divide-by-Zero Crash on Console
key_stories.summary: Return to Yoshi’s Island and Only Up builds crashed on boot due to a floating-point exception.  Investigation showed GCC had pipelined a mandatory divide into a branch delay slot, forcing a ÷0 on every run.
key_stories.challenge: Game crashed on real N64 with floating-point exception at ClipMario.
key_stories.process: Traced to compiler output, added ε check (0.01f) and rearranged calculations; duplicated fix in both repositories.
key_stories.outcome: Boot crash resolved; highlighted risks of maintaining two codebases.
key_stories.key_quote: The compiler decided to pipeline the division so I always divide by zero—that’s not my fault.

key_stories.title: Seesaw Goomba Set-Piece
key_stories.summary: Kaze built a dynamic seesaw platform: Mario smashes a rear crate, the plank pivots, bounces, and flattens a helmeted Goomba.
key_stories.challenge: Designing an interactive gag that feels physical yet runs on N64 limits.
key_stories.process: Modelled plank, programmed sine-based rotation, tuned bounce and speed, ensured predictable collision, tested on console.
key_stories.outcome: Animation is ‘beautiful’; next tasks are detaching Goomba and fine-tuning sound/physics.
key_stories.key_quote: The final image is beautiful—ending like this is the best thing ever.

key_stories.title: Missing Music from Composer
key_stories.summary: Current level lacks a dedicated track because composer Badub hasn’t checked in recently.
key_stories.challenge: Need original OST but composer absent.
key_stories.process: Kaze waits, considers stop-gap ideas, and invites chat OST suggestions.
key_stories.key_quote: I thought Badub was gonna make a song but Badub's been missing for a bit.
